utterances: In the meantime, there's more information today about the identies of the candidates for the Senate seat that Blagojevich is allegedly caught on tape talking about.
The criminal complaint alleges the governor allegedly told an adviser he might get some money upfront from someone identified as Candidate Five.
Blagojevich says, quote, that he'd raise 500 grand, and the other guy would raise a million, end quote, if he made Candidate Five a senator.
Attorneys for Congressman Jesse Jackson Jr. confirmed that he is Candidate Number Five.
But Jackson denies he offered Blagojevich anything for the seat.
Representative JESSE JACKSON, Jr. (Democrat, 2nd Congressional District of Illinois): I did not initiate or authorize anyone, at any time, to promise anything to Governor Blagojevich on my behalf.
I never sent a message or an emissary to the govenror to make an offer, to plead my case, or to propose a deal about a U.S.
Senate seat.
Period.
And Jackson went on to give the strong impression that regardless of all that has happened, he still wants to be, and will campaign to be, Illinois' next U.S.
senator.
David Schaper, NPR News, Chicago.
And on Wednesdays, our business report focuses on the workplace.
Today, taking a break from work.
For many, vacation is a time to veg on the beach or the couch.
Jared Sandberg writes the Cubicle Culture column for The Wall Street Journal.
He recently learned that vegging out may not be the best way to relax.
I didn't think anything was wrong with vegging, and then I made the mistake of speaking with a sociology professor - Geoffrey Godbey, at Penn State University - who studies leisure.
And he basically told me that all that vegging out by the pool is making me a dumber person over time.
It might make you a dumber person on the vacation, but over time?

Professor Godbey has this whole hierarchy of leisure, and the diversion - the sitting by the pool, the loafing, the vegging in front of the television - is a very low-level way to spend your leisure time.
There are higher levels of leisure.
Perhaps it's opera or something more cultured.
But even above that - and most important - is that you seek meaning and you bring to your leisure the same sort of industry that you might think would be better reserved for work.
Another twist on this is you write about one accountant in your column who spent his summers harvesting wheat.
Right.
Now this is obviously something people get paid to do, but as he described it, it was very fulfilling.
This is Warren Bainter.
He's an accountant in Oberlin, Kansas.

And basically, if he didn't go on 500-mile bike trips during his vacations, he would help one of his tax clients by sitting on a 30-foot-wide John Deere combine, threshing 500 bushels of wheat per hour.
To me it sounded utterly exhausting, but he loved it.
He sort of reached what people call a flow.
You let your mind slide into neutral, and I think there is a level of productivity there that was far more satisfying to him than if he were to sit on the beach getting sand stuck between his toes.
So it's not exactly always about your mind, but some level of gratification that one would get by doing something different?
He not only walks with Democratic presidents, but he...
Car wash.

Jamie Merisotis is CEO of the Lumina Foundation, which focuses on college access and the author of ""America Needs Talent."" He says if you look at the undocumented population in the U.S., many are young, talented people.
Well, post-secondary education is the key to integrating them into our society and taking them out of the shadows.
Again, Shai Reshef.
Even if you want to kick them out of the country, they will be much more desired wherever they go, so it's a win-win situation for everyone.
As for Miguel-Angel, he's put into practice what he's learning from his online business courses.
He's now the manager of the tiny trailer park where he lives.
Claudio Sanchez, NPR News.
We're going to go now to the western part of the country, where the amount of destruction by wildfires keeps going up.
Firefighters are dealing with unusually dry and hot conditions.
In California alone, the fires have destroyed close to 2,000 homes, and the state is only entering now what's traditionally the peak of its wildfire season.
NPR's Kirk Siegler reports on how there may not be a normal wildfire season anymore.

Here's how it used to be - the wildfire season would start in spring in the Southwest then gradually creep northward as the Rockies and Oregon and Washington dried out by mid-to-late summer, and then finally, a sometimes dramatic crescendo in California come fall.
That's how things normally went in the West.
But we don't have normal anymore.
Peter Goldmark is commissioner of public lands for the state of Washington, where due to the historic drought, the wildfire season started a good two months early.
A record 1 million acres of his state has burned this year, more than doubling last year, which had been the record.
It's been a horrific season.
There was even a wildfire in a coastal rain forest that scientists believe hasn't burned for at least 500 years.
In central Washington, an inferno raced into the city of Wenatchee.
Embers drifted more than a mile, igniting fruit packing warehouses.
These are very unusual conditions, and the open question is obviously hanging out there - are we seeing the effects of climate change, or is this within the natural variability that we should expect?
And I don't think anybody knows the answer to that.
Goldmark says he only knows that his state has to be better prepared if this really is the new normal.
The wildfires in the typically soggy Pacific Northwest have burned through fuels that are historically dry.
In Washington, three firefighters have died, and and down the West Coast blazes are burning at an intensity firefighters have never seen.
In California, this description has become almost cliche this year.
We were all just stunned at the extent and the ferocity of the fire and how quickly it jumped and moved.
On the Valley Fire, north of the Bay Area, evacuees like Peter Braun tell harrowing stories about the unpredictable nature of these fires.
We're basically fleeing, not evacuating.
Firefighters still haven't contained, let alone controlled, California's three largest and most destructive fires right now.
In some places, it's only just now safe to get in and begin assessing the scope of the damage.
The number of homes and businesses destroyed could keep going up.
Nicole Ganley is with the Association of California Insurance Companies.
Unfortunately, September has been so difficult in California and we're just about to go into October, which is really the high-danger time.
So fire officials and we as insurers will continue to brace.
Just consider that the five most destructive wildfires in U.S.
history all occurred in California in either October or early November, and most of those happened back in the normal years.
Kirk Siegler, NPR News.
Across the country, people and places are being transformed by choice or circumstance.
We're telling some of their stories this month in a series called Starting Over.
In this latest installment, we go to Seattle, where the average unemployment rate for people under the age of 25 is more than twice the national average.
Carolyn Adolph of KUOW reports on a young woman who changed her life by bridging the opportunity gap - that space between wanting a better life and actually getting it.
Thuy Pham's days used to end with a bus commute from her job in Seattle's International District to her home.
And I usually take number 60.
There was an advertisement on that bus.
I saw it, like, every day.
It said something about an opportunity gap and offering a way to get past it.
I don't understand it at all until one day that I really tired.
And I feel like - I think, like, when this life going to change?
Pham had a part-time job making sandwiches at this deli.
I'm making bahn mi over there.
So I standing ready and making for them.
Pham and her parents immigrated here from Vietnam five years ago.
This was the way she was supporting herself.
Putting the food on the table.
But at the same time, I also understand that without a education, I cannot - I cannot move on from this job.
I cannot, you know, like, move up the career.
It took time, but eventually she called the number in the ad on that bus.
A free work training program called Year Up accepted her.
It promises half a year of job skills training, and then half a year of company internship - a big, tough year.
There are some student cannot get through the program.
The first six months, I don't let it make me feel down.
I still keep going.
